A safe, low-cost and high-efficiency presodiation strategy for pouch-type sodium-ion capacitors with high energy density Congkai Sun a b Xiong Zhang a b d ⁎ Chen Li a Kai Wang a b d Xianzhong Sun a Fangyan Liu c d Zhong-Shuai Wu c d Yanwei Ma a b ⁎ a Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China Institute of Electrical Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China b School of Engineering Sciences, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China School of Engineering Sciences University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 China School of Engineering Sciences, University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, China c State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, Liaoning 116023, China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian, Liaoning 116023 China State Key Laboratory of Catalysis, Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, Liaoning 116023, China d Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, Liaoning 116023, China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy Chinese Academy of Sciences Dalian, Liaoning 116023 China Dalian National Laboratory for Clean Energy, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Dalian, Liaoning 116023, China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China. Institute of Electrical Engineering Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100190 China Graphical abstract We present a safe, low-cost and high-efficiency presodiation strategy by employing Na2C2O4 as the sacrificial salt employed in SICs for the first time. As the “zero-dead-mass” material, Na2C2O4 possesses a high presodiation efficiency of 100% when presodiation is completed which is comparable with that of metallic sodium. Sodium-ion capacitors (SICs) have attracted appreciable attention in virtue of the higher energy and power densities compared with their rivals, supercapacitors and sodium-ion batteries. Due to the lack of sodium resources in cathode, presodiation is critical for SICs to further augment performances. However, current presodiation strategy utilizes metallic sodium as the presodiation material. In this strategy, assembling/disassembling of half-cells is required, which is dangerous and increases the time and cost of SIC leading to the restriction of their industrialization and commercialization. Herein we present a safe, low-cost and high-efficiency presodiation strategy by first employing Na2C2O4 as the sacrificial salt applied in SICs. Na2C2O4 is environmentally friendly and possesses considerably low expenditure. No additional residues remain after sodium extraction ascribed to its “zero dead mass” property. When paired with commercial activated carbon as the cathode and commercial hard carbon as the anode, the constructed pouch-type SICs exhibit high energy and power densities of 91.7 Wh/kg and 13.1 kW/kg, respectively. This work shows a prospect of realizing the safe and low-cost manufacturing for high-performance SICs commercially. Keywords Presodiation material Sacrificial salt High efficiency Zero dead mass Sodium-ion capacitors Lithium-ion capacitors 1 Introduction With the ever-increasing concern on the human living environment, issues of environmental pollution and energy crisis urge the society to move towards clean and renewable energy storage systems (ESSs) using sustainable such as wind, solar and tidal energy [1–5]. However, these resources exhibit the characteristic of intermittency which are restrained and impacted by the time and geographic conditions [6,7]. Therefore, it is important and urgent to develop advanced sustainable ESSs. With the preponderance of stable output, electrical ESSs, such as supercapacitors (SCs) and lithium-ion batteries (LIBs), have been investigated considerably [8–18]. Supercapacitors (SCs) exhibit merits of high power densities and outstanding cycle life, while suffer from low energy density owning to the low operation voltage [19–22]. LIBs with high energy density are paid more and more attention and gradually being applied in the automotive market for plug-in electric vehicles (EVs) and hybrid EVs [23,24]. However, the power density and the cycle life need to be intensified derived from the charge storage mechanics of Faradaic reactions [25]. Besides, the amount of lithium resources in crust is only about 0.0017 wt%, and their geographical distribution are not even, which is responsible for the rising price of lithium compounds [26]. Fortunately, sodium resources have an amount of approximately 1300 times than that of lithium, and sodium possesses a suitable redox potential of −2.7 V [27–29]. This provides an opportunity to realize and construct sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) [30–43]. Besides, copper current collector can be substituted by the light and inexpensive aluminum, since aluminum does not form alloy with sodium at a low potential. As another sodium-based energy storage device, sodium-ion capacitors (SICs), which bridge the gap between SCs and SIBs, attract more and more attention due to the high energy and power densities [44–50]. Typically, they are composed of electrical double layer (EDL)-type cathode dominated by physical adsorption/desorption behavior and battery-type anode controlled by intercalation/deintercalation behavior [51,52]. During the charge process, sodium ions in the electrolyte migrate and intercalation to the lattice of the anode with Faradaic reactions and relevant anions simultaneously migrate and adsorb to the surface of the cathode with non-Faradaic reactions [53,54]. Opposite behaviors occur in which sodium ions and relevant anions return to the electrolyte in the subsequent discharge process. However, the cathode of SICs does not contain sodium sources. In order to replenish irreversible sodium-ion by forming the solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) and reversible sodium-ion by intercalating lithium-ion into the anode, it is imperative to add supplementary sodium sources in the system, namely presodiation [55]. Through presodiation process, the voltage window is widened by lowering the anode potential, hence the energy density can be enhanced according to Eq. (1): (1) E = 1 2 C V 2 , where E represents the energy density, C represents the capacitance and V represents voltage window. Current SICs constructed mostly utilize metallic sodium as the sacrificial sodium resource to perform the presodiation [46,56–59]. However, the manufacturing and commercialization of SICs is extremely impeded by the high chemical reactivity of metallic sodium which brings about potential safety issues, such as short-circuiting and relevant thermal runaway. Besides, additional time and expenditure is needed attributed to the additional processes of disassembly and reassembly for SICs. Cathode presodiation is regarded as a preferable strategy in which sacrificial salt is added into the cathode as the additive. Presodiation is performed by the initial charge process in which the additive decomposes and releases sodium ions into the electrolyte, followed by the migration and intercalation of sodium ions to the crystal lattice of the anode in the effect of electric field. Several sacrificial salts have been utilized to realize the presodiation, such as Na2S, Na2C6O6, Na2C6H2O6, Na2C4O4 and NaNH2 [60–63]. However, there are still several issues which need to be resolved. First, desodiated states such as S, C6O6, C6H2O6, C and NH2NH2, remain in the system as residues, which is not beneficial to boost presodiation efficiency and energy density after presodiation. Second, many of them, such as Na2S and NaNH2 are explosive, toxic and flammable and NaNH2 releases hazardous H2 after sodium extraction which do not ensure a safe presodiation. Third, some presodiation materials, such as Na2S, Na2C6O6, Na2C6H2O6 and NaNH2, are utilized as commercialized products, whose costs are still considerably expensive. Finally, it has a space to promote electrochemical performances, especially energy densities of SICs based on these sacrificial salts. All issues above hinder the industrialization and commercialization of SICs. The details are listed in Table S1. Therefore, it is critical and urgent to explore a safe, low-cost and high-efficiency presodiation material to construct high-performance SICs. Besides, devices utilized to achieve presodiation are coin-type and pouch-type devices need to be constructed in response to the large-scale manufacturing and the potential commercialization for high-performance SICs [55,64]. In this work, we present a safe, low-cost and high-efficiency presodiation strategy by utilizing sodium oxalate (Na2C2O4) as presodiation material of SICs for the first time. Na2C2O4 is environmentally friendly, possesses a considerably low cost and delivers a high specific capacity of 393.8 mAh/g which can be comparative with the theoretical value (400 mAh/g). No additional residues remain after presodiation since Na2C2O4 is “zero dead mass” sacrificial salt whose desodiated state, CO2, can be easily removed by a degassing process. Based on this presodiation material, high-performance pouch-type SICs were constructed through applying commercial activated carbon (AC) as the cathode and commercial hard carbon (HC) as the anode. Presodiation is realized by initial charging process through the decomposition of Na2C2O4 followed by the migration of Na+ and ClO4 − to the anode and cathode respectively as shown in Fig. 1 (a). Besides, not only AC serves as an active material for SIC but it can also lower voltage plateau of sodium extraction by catalyzing the decomposition for Na2C2O4. The energy and power densities can reach 91.7 Wh/kg and 13.1 kW/kg respectively based on the mass of active materials in both electrodes. This work can provide a guidance for large-scale manufacturing, promoting the industrialization and accelerating the commercialization of SICs with high performances. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials The commercial Na2C2O4, HC and AC (YP80F) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich, Wuyu Chemicals and Kuraray Chemicals, respectively. 2.2 Electrode preparation AC slurry was fabricated by mixing AC with conductive carbon (Super C45) and binder (PVdF) in a mass ratio of 80:10:10 dispersed in N-methyl pyrrolidone (NMP). Na2C2O4 used in this experiment was all treated by a ball milling process for 6 h at a rotating speed of 500 r/min. Na2C2O4 slurry was fabricated by mixing Na2C2O4 with Super C45 and PVdF in a mass ratio of 80:15:5 dispersed in NMP. AC/Na2C2O4 slurry was prepared by mixing AC with Na2C2O4, Super C45 and PVdF in a mass ratio of 40:40:15:5 dispersed in NMP. AC, Na2C2O4 and AC/Na2C2O4 electrodes were prepared by coating each slurry on current collector of carbon coated aluminum foil. HC slurry was composed of HC and Super C45 and PVdF in a mass ratio of 80:15:5 dispersed in NMP. HC electrode was fabricated by coating each slurry on current collector of copper foil. Before the coating process, ball milling treatments were carried out for all slurries for 6 h at a rotating speed of 500 r/min. The loading of active material in both electrodes was around 1 mg/cm2. 2.3 Physicochemical characterization The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were obtained from a Bruker D8 X-ray diffractometer at 40 kV and 40 mA with Cu Kα radiation. SEM images were acquired using the CARL Zeiss SIGMA (Germany) to measure the morphology of electrode materials. 2.4 Electrochemical measurements Half cells were constructed using sodium metal disk as the anode. Considering the gas generated, conventional coin-type cells were not introduced. Instead, a specific mold possessing a big internal space was employed to buffer the change of pressure. Hence, there is no additional gas removal process for this mold. SIC was assembled in three-electrode system, in which AC/Na2C2O4 electrode, HC electrode, and sodium metal disk served as working, counter and reference electrodes, respectively. The assembled SIC was pouch-typed which have a rectangle-shaped electrode with the size of 35 mm × 40 mm. All systems were assembled in a glove box under an argon atmosphere with H2O and O2 content all below 0.1 ppm. The separator was glass fiber (Whatman), and the electrolyte was 1 M NaClO4 in ethylene carbonate (EC) and propylene carbonate (PC) (1:1, vol%) with 5% fluoroethylene carbonate (FEC). A degassing process was performed after presodiation. Cyclic voltammetry was measured by EC lab (Bio-Logic VMP3, France). Galvanostatic charge–discharge, rate charge–discharge and cyclic performance were tested by Neware battery testing system (CT-4008, China) and Arbin Instruments (MSTAT4, USA). The energy and power density were obtained according to Eqs. (2) and (3): (2) E = I ∫ U d t m , (3) P = U m I m , where U, U m, I, and m represents the voltage, the average discharge voltage, the current and the mass of active materials of both cathode and anode, respectively. 3 Results and discussion It is generally recognized that different presodiation materials correspond to different desodiated states, which can be divided into gas, liquid and solid apart from sodium-ion. It should be noted that desodiated states of liquid and solid can be not removed from the system and will remain as the residues causing an increasing mass of the system. Here we introduce the concept of presodiation efficiency which is defined by the ratio of specific capacity of two presodiation materials. Among them, metallic sodium possesses a largest specific capacity, specific capacity of metallic sodium acts as the denominator. Therefore, the definition of presodiation efficiency is modified to the ratio of specific capacity of presodiation material to that of metallic sodium according to Eq. (4): (4) η = C P M ' C N a × 100 % , where η represents presodiation efficiency, C Na represents the specific capacity of metallic sodium, and C′PM represents the specific capacity of presodiation material after presodiation excluding gas produced according to the relevant sodium extraction equation. Besides, specific capacity has a connection with molar mass of presodiation material after presodiation according to Eq. (5): (5) C P M ' = Q m P M ' = r P M n N a F n N a N N a M P M ' = r P M F N N a M P M ' , where n represents the amount of substance, m′PM represents the mass of presodiation material after presodiation, Q represents the capacity presodiation materials provide, M′PM represents molar mass of presodiation material after presodiation excluding gas produced according to the relevant sodium extraction equation, r PM represents the ratio of sodium extraction from presodiation material (typically 1), n Na represents the amount of substance of sodium delivered, N Na represents the number of sodium per molecular formula, F represents Faraday constant. Hence, presodiation efficiency has a connection with molar mass of presodiation material after presodiation according to Eq. (6): (6) η = r P M M N a M P M ' N N a × 100 % , where M Na represents molar mass of metallic sodium. From the equation, it is beneficial for the decrease of M′PM/N Na to boost the value of η, guiding us to utilize presodiation material with small M′PM/N Na. Moreover, energy density has a connection with molar mass of presodiation material after presodiation according to Eq. (7): (7) E d e n s i t y ' = 1 2 ∙ E m P M ' + m o t h e r s = 1 2 ∙ E Q r P M F M P M ' N N a + m o t h e r s , where E represents total energy, and m others represents the mass of system excluding presodiation material. From the equation, it is beneficial to lower M′PM/N Na for obtaining a high E′density, also guiding us to employ presodiation material with small M′PM/N Na. The analyses above confirm that small M′PM/N Na has a positive effect on the enhancement of presodiation efficiency and energy density after presodiation. Different values of M′PM/N Na and η for different presodiation materials are shown in Fig. 1(b), and more details can be seen in Table S2. It can be seen that Na2C2O4 possesses a lowest M′PM/N Na, therefore the highest presodiation efficiency which is equivalent to that of metallic sodium. This enables Na2C2O4 as the “zero-dead-mass” sacrificial salt to perform a high-efficiency presodiation. Cyclic voltammograms (CVs) and galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles of Na2C2O4/AC electrode are shown in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 2(a), the initial CV cycle curves exhibit a broad and intensive peak starting from 3.7 V and reaching the summit at 4.0 V vs. Na+/Na originated from the oxidation of Na2C2O4 according to Eq. (8) [65]: (8) N a 2 C 2 O 4 → 2 C O 2 + 2 N a + + 2 e - , The low oxidation potential of 4.0 V not only ensures sodium extraction but also avoids oxidization of the electrolyte. Besides, the value is lower than that reported by Guo’s group [65]. The reason is the double effect of AC. AC is not only the active material of cathode for SIC, it also possesses a high specific surface area (SSA) of 1901.6 m2/g according to the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method as shown in Fig. S1, which lowers oxidation potential of Na2C2O4 on account of the catalysis effect [65,66]. In subsequent CV cycles the peak disappears. Na2C2O4 does not contribute to the capacity any more, which conforms to the criterion of sacrificial salts to be presodiation materials [67]. Moreover, galvanostatic charge–discharge profiles are shown in Fig. 2(b). The initial charge process was implemented to 4.4 V. A plateau can be obviously observed between 3.7 and 4.1 V, which is attributed to the decomposition of Na2C2O4. The specific capacity of Na2C2O4/AC electrode is 554.8 mAh/g based on the mass of Na2C2O4. The value is higher than the theoretical specific capacity (400 mAh/g) of Na2C2O4 and the additional capacity is mainly contributed by AC. As shown in Fig. S2, AC electrode delivers an initial specific capacity of 161.0 mAh/g when charged to 4.4 V. It can be calculated that added Na2C2O4 exhibits a specific capacity of 393.8 mAh/g with a decomposition rate of almost 100%. In the second cycle, Na2C2O4/AC electrode decays intensely, showing the capacity irreversibility of Na2C2O4. Therefore, Na2C2O4 can act as a preferable presodiation material corresponding to the criterion [67]. For comparison, the electrochemical performances of Na2C2O4 electrode which did not contain AC were also investigated. As shown in Fig. S3, the summit of peak is located at 4.4 V from CV profiles and galvanostatic charging platform is also located at 4.4 V, much higher than that of Na2C2O4/AC electrode. Besides, the delivered specific capacity is below 40 mAh/g, much lower than that of Na2C2O4/AC electrode. It is also ascribed to the catalytic effect of AC for Na2C2O4 to lower oxidation potential [65,66]. Rate experiments were carried out for Na2C2O4/AC electrode as shown in Fig. 2c. The specific capacity is 60.5 mAh/g at a low current density of 0.05 A/g, and it gradually decreases with the increase of current density. When changing to a high current density of 4 A/g, a high value of 35.2 mAh/g can be still obtained. Moreover, the electrode has a stable cyclic property after 500 cycles at the current density of 0.05 A/g as shown in Fig. 2d. The good electrochemical performances of half cells pave the way for those of subsequent full devices. Generally, it is beneficial to upgrade the cut-off voltage for the decomposition of Na2C2O4. However, considering the oxidation of electrolyte, it is inadvisable to charge to a quite high voltage. Thus, there exists a suitable charge cut-off voltage to perform presodiation. Fig. 3 shows the specific capacities of AC and Na2C2O4/AC electrodes along with the increase of charge cut-off voltage and the relevant decomposition rate of Na2C2O4 in Na2C2O4/AC electrode. We can see that the decomposition of Na2C2O4 starts from 3.7 V which is consistent with the CV and galvanostatic charge–discharge curves (Fig. 2a and b). Decomposition rate is promptly elevated with raising charge cut-off voltage. However, it elevates slowly when the voltage surpasses 4.0 V and the value has nearly no fluctuation when the voltage surpasses 4.2 V. It denotes that decomposition rate does not change when the charge voltage reaches 4.2 V. Although the specific capacity of Na2C2O4/AC electrodes continues increasing when charged to over 4.2 V, it is not contributed by Na2C2O4 but by AC. Consequently, a cut-off voltage of 4.2 V is selected for presodiation of SICs. The microstructures of utilized materials are analyzed by SEM. Na2C2O4 and AC powders look homogeneous and their sizes are several micrometers from Fig. 4 a–d. Although Na2C2O4/AC composite electrode seems less homogeneous due to the introduction of the binder and conductive carbon as shown in Fig. 4e and f, Na2C2O4 particles are homogeneous in Na2C2O4/AC electrode from the distribution of elements as shown in Fig. S4. It suggests that ball milling treatment has no obvious negative effect on the morphology. After presodiation and after the cycle, from Fig. 4g–j, the microscale is still reserved, and pores and voids can be observed. This is stemmed from the generation of CO2, the decomposition product of Na2C2O4. Pores and voids are beneficial for the electrolyte and sodium-ion to diffuse through the microstructure of AC [62]. SEM images of cross section and images of optical microscopy for pristine Na2C2O4/AC electrode and Na2C2O4/AC electrode after presodiation, after 1500 cycles and after 10,000 cycles are shown in Figs. S5 and S6. Pores and voids are also observed. It can be inferred that not only the surface of electrode generates gas, but also internal area is involved in favor of the decomposition of Na2C2O4. During the whole experimental process, the integrity of electrode structure is retained and there are no imperfections, such as fractures or cracks. Besides, a good electrode adhesion to the current collector is reserved. The stability of the electrode structure guarantees that our constructed pouch-type SICs have excellent electrochemical performances. Crystal structures were characterized by XRD patterns. As shown in Fig. 5 , Na2C2O4 power has an intense peak at 2θ degree of 31.6° corresponding to crystal face of (−1 1 1), which is remained in Na2C2O4 and Na2C2O4/AC electrode. While the characterized peak disappears after presodiation. It should be noted that the electrode after presodiation needs to be immersed in a solvent of dimethyl carbonate (DMC) in order to remove the electrolyte on the surface. To confirm that Na2C2O4 does not dissolve in DMC, Na2C2O4/AC electrode was immersed in DMC for a day. As shown in Fig. S7, the characterized peak of Na2C2O4 is observed. Therefore, the results support that Na2C2O4 power in Na2C2O4/AC electrode decomposes completely after presodiation which lays a foundation for no longer contributing to the specific capacity for subsequent tests. Pouch-type SICs were constructed by employing the commercial HC as the anode and the Na2C2O4/AC composite as the cathode, and the photo image is shown in Fig. S8. As charges stored in both electrodes should be equal, the mass ratio of AC to HC and Na2C2O4 must be well-balanced to obtain the maximum capacity from both materials. Rate performances of AC and HC are shown in Fig. S9. The specific capacity ratios of cathode to anode are rapidly upgraded and approach to 1:1 when current densities are gradually increased. Hence a mass ratio of 1:1 is selected. Considering the cut-off voltage of 4.2 V above-mentioned, the potential of cathode should be slightly higher than 4.2 V. When charged to 4.2 V, AC electrode can exhibit a specific capacity of 79.2 mAh/g as shown in Fig. S2. Na2C2O4 delivers a charging capacity of 393.8 mAh/g. Meanwhile, HC has an initial discharging capacity of 509.8 mAh/g as shown in Fig. S10. It can be readily calculated that the mass ratio of Na2C2O4 to HC should be below 1.09. Herein, equal masses of Na2C2O4 and AC are selected. Galvanostatic presodiation was implemented during the charging process in which the sacrificial salt in the composite electrode delivered sodium ions to the electrolyte with upgrading the electrode potential, while the anode received the sodium-ion from the electrolyte with degrading the electrode potential. The driving force is originated from the effect of electric field. It gives rise to a result that the cathode reached a higher potential whereas the anode reached a lower potential. Fig. 6 shows the voltage profiles of the initial charge of pouch-type SICs at a current density of 0.025 A/g with and without presodiation. As shown in Fig. 6a, when charged to a voltage of 3.400 V, potentials of cathode and anode reach 4.275 and 0.875 V respectively without presodiation. As the cathode does not contain sodium sources, sodium ions intercalated into HC come from the electrolyte. Considering the high potential of anode, HC has an insufficient sodium-ion intercalating and is far from well sodiated. In contrast, when the cathode contains sodium sources, Na2C2O4, as shown in Fig. 6b, a fixed charging voltage of 4.200 V is selected which allows Na2C2O4 to decompose between 3.7 and 4.1 V and sodium-ion delivered to intercalate into the structure of anode, accompanying by the potentials of cathode and anode reaching 4.265 and 0.065 V, respectively. In view of the low electrode potential of anode, HC has a sufficient sodium-ion intercalation and is well presodiated after the addition of Na2C2O4. Moreover, the amount of sodium-ion intercalated into the anode can be easily adjusted by the content of Na2C2O4. As shown in Fig. S11, when the mass ratio of Na2C2O4 to AC is decreased to 1:1.5, a minimum anode potential of 0.092 V can be obtained, higher than the ratio of 1:1, which indicates that high content of Na2C2O4 can induce high amount of sodium-ion intercalated. Since anode potential is always higher than 0 V, safety issues can be eliminated which shows our proposed presodiation strategy is not only effective but also safe to show a prospect of realizing large-scale manufacturing for high-performance pouch-type SICs. Galvanostatic charge–discharge measurements were implemented in a voltage range of 2.0–4.0 V at different current densities of 0.1, 1 and 10 A/g after presodiation. Triangular characteristics can be observed, which indicates capacitive behaviors especially at low current densities as shown in Fig. 7 . The anode displays a narrow potential oscillation ranged from 0.095 to 0.39 V, 0.073 to 0.46 V and 0.088 to 0.53 V at a current density of 0.1, 1 and 10 A/g, respectively. As anode potential is always above 0 V, our proposed presodiation strategy is safe because it avoids the formation of sodium dendrite and refrains from the risks of short-circuiting and relevant thermal runaway. Besides, the maximum cathode potentials are 4.095, 4.073 and 4.088 V respectively which restrict the oxidation of the electrolyte, whereas the minimum cathode potentials are 2.39, 2.46 and 2.53 V, always above 1.9 V vs. Na+/Na (i.e. 2.2 V vs. Li+/Li), preventing from the potential formation of SEI layer on the surface of AC [60,68]. Voltage drops increase at higher current densities, mainly affected by the electrochemical polarization. Besides, it can be seen from the Fig. 7 that capacitive behaviors deviate slightly from the linearity at high current density, which is induced by the deviation of linearity for the cathode. These results indicate that after presodiation, it is feasible to obtain a satisfactory galvanostatic charge–discharge process. Rate tests of pouch-type SICs were investigated between 2.0 and 4.0 V at different current densities of 0.05–10 A/g. At a low current density, the specific capacitance is above 50 F/g based on the mass of active materials in both electrodes as shown in Fig. 8 a, and capacitance fade is aggravated with the enlarged current density. Even at a high current density of 10 A/g, a specific capacitance of ~10 F/g still can be acquired, validating our designed pouch-type SICs have excellent rate performance. Cyclic life between 2.0 and 4.0 V at a current density of 1 A/g is shown in Fig. 8b. The capacitance retention is 82.3% after the cycle. For the comparison, cyclic performances of AC and HC electrodes were also tested at 1 A/g. As shown in Fig. S12, they exhibit good cycle life for 500 cycles, and no obvious capacity decay is observed. The decay of SIC is attributed to the increased electrochemical impedance during the cyclic process as shown in Fig. S13. Furthermore, traditional AC//HC pouch-type SIC presodiated by metallic sodium were also assembled to test the cyclic life. The capacitance fades to 52% only after 1000 cycles as shown in Fig. S14. This indicates that it is much better to presodiate using sacrificial salt than metallic sodium. Ragone plots are shown in Fig. 8(c) by comparing SICs in other literatures. The devices can exhibit an energy density of 91.7 Wh/kg at a power density of 37.5 W/kg and a power density of 13.1 kW/kg at an energy density of 18.1 Wh/kg, which are outstanding than other SICs reported: Na2S/AC//Sn4P3 (63.4 Wh/kg at 50.1 W/kg and 6.0 kW/kg at 15 Wh/kg) [60], Na2C6O6/AC//nitrogen-doped hierarchical porous carbon (NHPC) (33.0 Wh/kg at 98.7 W/kg and 4.0 kW/kg at 2.4 Wh/kg) [61], Na2C6H2O6/AC//NHPC (18.9 Wh/kg at 99.1 W/kg and 4.0 kW/kg at 2.1 Wh/kg) [61], Na2C4O4/AC//HC (77.4 Wh/kg at 59.8 W/kg and 2.1 kW/kg at 39.9 Wh/kg) [62] and NaNH2/AC//HC (41.3 Wh/kg at 104.2 W/kg and 3.9 kW/kg at 9.1 Wh/kg) [63]. Furthermore, 180 light-emitting diode (LED) bulbs can be easily lighted up by our constructed pouch-type SIC as shown in Fig. 8(d). These results indicate that sodium-ion supplied by the decomposition of Na2C2O4 can stably intercalate and deintercalate to the structure of anode with high efficiency. All the results above demonstrate that our proposed presodiation strategy is safe, low-cost and high-efficiency. In the strategy, AC acts as double roles, in which AC serves not only as the active material of pouch-type SICs but also catalyzes the decomposition of Na2C2O4 in Na2C2O4/AC composite electrode. Moreover, Na2C2O4 is utilized as an excellent presodiation material for pouch-type SICs due to the following reasons. First, Na2C2O4 is environmentally friendly and has a low decomposition voltage of 4.0 V to avoid the potential safety issues. Second, Na2C2O4 has a quite low expenditure. Third, after presodiation no residues remain in the system as “zero dead mass” property of Na2C2O4, in turn decreasing the total mass and improving the presodiation efficiency. Besides, pouch-type SICs in this strategy do not need negative electrode to be perforated which can reduce the practical time and costs of presodiation technology. Finally, pouch-type SICs employing Na2C2O4 as the sacrificial salt presents excellent electrochemical performances. 4 Conclusions We present a safe, low-cost and high-efficiency presodiation strategy by employing of Na2C2O4 as the presodiation material of pouch-type SICs for the first time. As the “zero dead mass” material, Na2C2O4 is low-cost, environmentally friendly and delivers a specific capacity of 393.8 mAh/g. No residues remain after presodiation which is beneficial for the increase of presodiation and energy density considering the total mass of the system. Paired with commercial AC as the cathode and commercial HC as the anode, pouch-type SICs are constructed with Na2C2O4 as the presodiation material. AC plays two-fold roles in which AC acts not only as the active material of pouch-type SICs but also catalyzes the decomposition of Na2C2O4 in Na2C2O4/AC composite electrode. The assembled pouch-type SICs displays energy and power densities of 91.7 Wh/kg and 13.1 kW/kg, respectively. This work successfully overcomes the major scientific bottleneck focusing on the issue of presodiation for SICs, which offers important guidance for the large-scale manufacturing in future commercialization of SICs. coredata.dc:description: Sodium-ion capacitors (SICs) have attracted appreciable attention in virtue of the higher energy and power densities compared with their rivals, supercapacitors and sodium-ion batteries. Due to the lack of sodium resources in cathode, presodiation is critical for SICs to further augment performances. However, current presodiation strategy utilizes metallic sodium as the presodiation material. In this strategy, assembling/disassembling of half-cells is required, which is dangerous and increases the time and cost of SIC leading to the restriction of their industrialization and commercialization. Herein we present a safe, low-cost and high-efficiency presodiation strategy by first employing Na2C2O4 as the sacrificial salt applied in SICs. Na2C2O4 is environmentally friendly and possesses considerably low expenditure. No additional residues remain after sodium extraction ascribed to its “zero dead mass” property. When paired with commercial activated carbon as the cathode and commercial hard carbon as the anode, the constructed pouch-type SICs exhibit high energy and power densities of 91.7 Wh/kg and 13.1 kW/kg, respectively. This work shows a prospect of realizing the safe and low-cost manufacturing for high-performance SICs commercially.

coredata.dc:title: A safe, low-cost and high-efficiency presodiation strategy for pouch-type sodium-ion capacitors with high energy density
